The dual use of etcd certificates as serving and client certs is unfortunate, but known

comments.body: Does this set it to "" and prevent the defaulting in config-default?

Yes, which means the only way to change this on an existing cluster is to modify the existing kube-env in metadata.

I'm not sure of a better way to handle updates. Either, we do this, and changing the existing value is kinda gross, or we go off of the config-default value, and we (possibly surprisingly) update the value on existing clusters. This felt like the less intrusive approach.
Is there a well defined procedure for changing existing cluster parameters generally?

we definitely should not update the value on existing clusters during upgrade. existing workloads should continue to run as-is on an upgraded cluster.

updating the default for new clusters is what I'd like to see, though the interaction between metadata env and the config-default.sh scripts is not clear to me (I can't tell which runs first, which informs the other, etc).

comments.body: @cjcullen I assume something similar is needed in the GKE bring-up scripts. What does the client certificate created by GKE currently look like?

Same as what GCE used to do, except w/ "client" as the cn. I'd rather not mint new client certificates on GKE w/ the system:masters group. The admin client cert is mostly a legacy thing on GKE. And if users want to continue having their "client" user have some permissions, they can add the RBAC binding that allows that (before turning off ABAC).

I don't know what the upgrade story is going to look like on GCE.
I think upgrade looks like "keep existing ABAC policy file in place, unioned with RBAC policy", so all existing identities, tokens, certs, etc, keep working as-is.

I think that's a reasonable answer for the old user-facing client certs. If you want to migrate to RBAC-only, but want your cert to keep having admin permissions, you should create a binding before making it lose power.

On GCE, the client cert is still probably the best authn method, so it makes sense to keep supporting it w/ the new model (add the system:masters group to new certs). I'm going to punt on it right now for GKE, but I'd like it if we no longer minted new per-cluster admin certs.

comments.body: Why are hiding curl errors a good thing?  Trying to decide about pulling this into 1.4.   I'm not seeing the real need.  It's just 2 additional echos and this, which I don't understand.

My experience shows that if the error is real, it is also present in stdout. However, the main purpose of this change is to avoid logs like;

```
% Total    % Received % Xferd  Average Speed   Time    Time     Time  Current
                                 Dload  Upload   Total   Spent    Left  Speed
  0     0    0     0    0     0      0      0 --:--:-- --:--:-- --:--:--     0
```

that are split randomly over other logs (a part of it here, a part somewhere else, another part in yet another place) - this is super annoying and makes debugging much harder.
Would `--silent --show-error` be a better choice than hiding everything?
SGTM - see #33016

comments.body: Why change this?

Because now that `OS_DISTRIBUTION` defaults to `gci`, one doesn't have to set `KUBE_OS_DISTRIBUTION` any more to start a GCI cluster. In that case, the old logic would fail.

For other distros on this list, they all have to set `KUBE_OS_DISTRIBUTION` as before, but `OS_DISTRIBUTION` will always equal to `KUBE_OS_DISTRIBUTION`, so it should work for them too. Are you thinking of anything that could potentially break because of this change?
Now that `OS_DISTRIBUTION` defaults to `gci`, one doesn't have to set `KUBE_OS_DISTRIBUTION=gci` any more to start a GCI cluster, and the old logic will start to fail in this case.
Thanks for explaining. I was concerned it wasn't set in all paths that call this, but on looking more it looks fine.

comments.body:
Nit: per our chosen bash style guide [[ is prefered over [

https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/kubernetes/blob/master/docs/devel/coding-conventions.md
The rest of the file does 2 space indentation as well.
in my limited testing, I think using `[` instead of `[[` is what broke this for GCE, though I can't entirely explain why.

These actually evaluate differently. The `[[ -n` does the right thing with array expansion, whereas `[` seems to, well, deal poorly. I love bash:

``` console
zml@zml:~$ args=("--foo" "--bar" "--blatz")
zml@zml:~$ if [[ -n "${args[@]:-}" ]]; then echo "WUMPUS"; fi
WUMPUS
zml@zml:~$ if [ -n "${args[@]:-}" ]; then echo "WUMPUS"; fi
-bash: [: too many arguments
```
that's what I discovered in my testing, too, but I didn't see that error in the build log on Jenkins, so I was/am confused.

wait no, I'm just bad at searching the log:

```
/jenkins-master-data/jobs/kubernetes-e2e-gce-parallel/workspace/kubernetes/hack/e2e-internal/../../cluster/../cluster/gce/../../cluster/common.sh: line 83: [: too many arguments
```

comments.body: Also check to see if a bearer token is present?

The previous code just assumes that all of the necessary vars are set, and after a transition period I'd like to remove the username/password option from all cloud providers and transition everyone to using bearer tokens. I suppose we could skip writing any credentials to the kubeconfig file if they aren't set, but that means there is a bug in the startup scripts and the user won't be able to interact with their cluster.
